text:
February 14, 2017 5:36 pm Alberta NDPâ€™s â€˜building a pipelineâ€¦to your heartâ€™ Valentine receives mixed messages online By Alyssa Julie News Talk 770 
An Alberta NDP valentine with Premier Rachel Notley's photo on it is garnering mixed reaction Feb. 14, 2017. @AlbertaNDP Twitter What is this?

The Alberta NDP has stirred up controversy on Twitter with a Valentineâ€™s Day message to Albertans. 
The valentine features a smiling Rachel Notley and reads: â€œbuilding a pipeline â€¦ to your heart.â€ Happy Valentine's Day from all of us at the Alberta NDP. pic.twitter.com/PAY6B8MMxQ 
â€” Josh McLean (@RadioMcLean) February 14, 2017 @MetlSlyme @albertaNDP I'm not even mad. This is amazing. 
â€” Graham Mosimann (@GrahamMosimann) February 14, 2017 @albertaNDP Happy Valentine's Day! I'm so proud to be Albertan right now! You guys are knocking it out of the park! ğŸ’–ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ‰ğŸ¾ğŸ† #naturalleadership 
â€” Paige (@paigerosner) February 14, 2017 
The Trudeau administration gave its seal of approval to the two pipelines in December 2016. The prime minister said it was Albertaâ€™s climate leadership that opened the door to the pipeline approvals. 
But the province has experienced quite a bit of backlash over its climate policies, including the much-maligned carbon tax , which came into effect Jan. 1. 
Watch below: What will Albertaâ€™s carbon tax cost you? Laurel Gregory takes a look. 
Several people on Twitter appeared frustrated, or even angered by the governmentâ€™s playful message. @albertaNDP more like "piling a suffocating deficit on your future through our incompetent management" #ableg #FireNotley #ScrapTheNDP 
â€” Lisa (@MissCareless198) February 14, 2017 
Janet Brown, a political analyst from Calgary, told News Talk 770 she expects the greeting will simply reinforce Albertansâ€™ opinions on the NDP. 
â€œIf it was an attempt to change anyoneâ€™s mind or make them feel any better about the NDP , it was probably misguided,â€ Brown said. 
â€œIf it was just a way to express something jovial to people who already support you, then it wasnâ€™t a bad idea.â€ 
While several people responded with anger over the governmentâ€™s policies, especially as the Alberta economy continues to struggle in the wake of low oil prices, others sought to shine a spotlight on the perceived environmental impact of the pipelines and the impact on First Nations communities. 
â€” Katie Jensen (@katiejensen) February 14, 2017 @albertaNDP Right through the hearts of First Nations people. Can you get any more tone deaf?!
